intro: Tetrastigma quadridens, commonly known as the four-toothed crossvine, is a climbing vine native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Vitaceae family and is characterized by its woody stems and tendrils that help it climb. The plant has compound leaves with opposite arrangement, and its flowers are small, greenish-yellow, and clustered in panicles. Tetrastigma quadridens produces small, round berries that are typically yellow or red when mature. It is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as forests and is used in traditional medicine in some regions.
